docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Milton I. Roemer, a physician whose research on public health systems helped to shape health policy in the United States and other countries, died on Jan. 3 at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles. Dr. Roemer retired in 1986 as a professor in the U.C.L.A. School of Public Health's Department of Health Services.

headline.main: Milton Roemer, H.M.O. Advocate, Dies at 84

docs.snippet: Dr. Milton I. Roemer, a physician whose research on public health systems helped to shape health policy in the United States and other countries, died on Jan. 3 at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 84 and lived in Los Angeles.    Dr. Roemer retired in...

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST March, when William J. Lansing resigned as chairman of the Fingerhut Companies to become chief executive of NBC Internet Inc., he received a substantial compensation package: an $800,000 salary, a $1.2 million annual bonus, options on one million shares and restricted shares then worth $12 million. NBCi also gave him a $4 million interest-free loan to buy a house. Mr. Lansing, whose jumbo home loan was roughly the size of NBCi's revenue for the first quarter of 2000, is but one of many stock-rich chief executives who now owe substantial sums of money to their employers. At small Internet companies and blue-chip industrial concerns, shareholders are extending hundreds of millions of dollars in credit with favorable rates to chief executives and other top officers to buy homes or stock, or to get their personal financial houses in order.

headline.main: Owing More Than Loyalty to a Company You Run

docs.abstract: Many publicly held companies make loans to chief executives and higher managers that carry far more lenient terms than marketplace offers, and companies often forgive the debts; companies carry loans on their books as assets, but they can quickly turn into liabilities; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration intends to support state laws expanding the rights of patients in disputes with health maintenance organizations, a matter that is before the Supreme Court, aides to President-elect George W. Bush say. Two court cases, one from Texas and the other from Illinois, raise the question of whether states may require H.M.O.'s to provide an independent review after they rule that a specific treatment is not medically necessary. A federal appeals court struck down the Texas law, but another federal appeals court upheld a very similar law adopted in Illinois.

headline.main: Bush to Back States' Laws On Rights For Patients

docs.abstract: Pres-elect George W Bush says he intends to support state laws expanding rights of patients in disputes with health maintenance organizations, a matter that is before Supreme Court; members of Congress say chances for passage of legislation defining patients' rights has increased, in part because Democrats have gained several Senate seats in November elections (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A ROOT canal should cost more than $50. Le Loi knows this now. He didn't know it on the February morning when he and his toothache walked into a tiny dental office in Chinatown. Seven people were already waiting in line when he arrived. He riffled through magazines while he waited. None were written in his native Vietnamese, so he looked at the pictures.
docs.abstract: Article on large number of imposters living in New York City; professions of choice, in order of popularity, are medical doctors, registered nurses, massage therapists, pharmacists and dentists; some cases detailed; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Giuliani administration has reached an agreement with municipal unions on a deal that will expand health care and other benefits for nearly 300,000 city workers and 200,000 municipal retirees. The accord, reached in talks separate from the continuing negotiations for a wage agreement, expands mental health and retirement benefits and increases by about $175 per worker the city's contribution to a health and welfare fund, which reimburses city workers for dental and optical care.

headline.main: City and Municipal Unions Reach Accord on Expanded Benefits

docs.abstract: New York City and its municipal unions reach agreement that will expand benefits for nearly 300,000 city workers and 200,000 retirees (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Tobacco opponents in Wisconsin and Washington say Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who is President-elect George W. Bush's choice to head the Health and Human Services Department, has not vigorously pursued tobacco control initiatives, in part because of ties to executives of Philip Morris, the cigarette maker. As the parent corporation of two Wisconsin companies -- the Miller Brewing Company and Oscar Mayer Foods, a division of Kraft Foods -- Philip Morris is one of Wisconsin's largest employers. Mr. Thompson's aides and Philip Morris officials say it is appropriate that he has worked closely with company executives over the 14 years he has been Wisconsin's governor.

headline.main: Choice for Health Secretary Is Faulted on Tobacco Issue

docs.abstract: Tobacco opponents in Wisconsin and Washington say Gov Tommy G Thompson, Pres-elect Bush's choice to head Health and Human Services Dept, has not vigorously pursued tobacco control initiatives, in part because of ties to executives of Philip Morris, cigarette maker; Thompson's aides and Philip Morris officials say it is appropriate that Thompson worked closely with executives of Philip Morris, which is one of Wisconsin's largest employers; tobacco opponents raise concerns about Thompson's participation in two international trips financed largely by Philip Morris, as well as more than $72,000 in contributions to him from employees and executives of comapny; spokesman for Bush says Thompson has record of opposing youth access to tobacco; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Tobacco opponents in Wisconsin and Washington say Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who is President-elect George W. Bush's choice to head the Health and Human Services Department, has not vigorously pursued tobacco control initiatives, in part...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton took a walk down memory lane today -- or to be more exact, down Elm Street -- in the center of a city that was so crucial nearly nine years ago to his presidential election. Mr. Clinton ducked into the Merrimack Restaurant, one of his haunts here in the 1992 campaign, and requested the same waitress, Jane Davis, who had served him then and had once written in the local newspaper that he was the best tipper of all the candidates who came through.

headline.main: In New Hampshire, Clinton's Heart Is on His Sleeve

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton visits Manchester, NH, city that was so crucial to his presidential election in 1992, and reminisces about that campaign; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was appointed to three Senate committees today, including one that has jurisdiction over health care, the very issue she tried to put her stamp on as first lady. Mrs. Clinton's appointment to the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee came as somewhat of a surprise, since she has been so closely identified in Washington with the Clinton administration's failed attempt to overhaul the nation's health care system in 1993.

headline.main: For Hillary Clinton, a Health Care Assignment

docs.abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton is appointed to three Senate committees, including Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, which has jurisdiction over health care, very issue she tried to put her stamp on as first lady; she is also appointed to Environment and Public Works Committee, and Budget Committee (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Theodore J. Forstmann was planning to spend the winter in Los Angeles as usual, avoiding the New York weather and relaxing away from the Fifth Avenue office of the leveraged buyout firm bearing his name. He just canceled his vacation plans.

headline.main: It's Buying Time Again; With Rivals Regrouping, Forstmann Prepares to Pounce

docs.abstract: Forstmann Little is preparing to make major acquisitions while rival leveraged buyout firms regroup; competitors, like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, were buying into many highly leveraged telecommunications and technology investments while Theodore J Forstmann was squirreling away his money--over $4 billion--in special subordinated-debt fund and his more traditional equity fund, waiting for moment to make acquisitions; now just about everybody else is down, and Forstmann is feeling up; chart lists Forstmann's current holdings; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Theodore J. Forstmann was planning to spend the winter in Los Angeles as usual, avoiding the New York weather and relaxing away from the Fifth Avenue office of the leveraged buyout firm bearing his name.    He just canceled his vacation plans.
